title-group.article-title: A Schumpeterian Model of Entrepreneurship, Innovation, and Regional Economic Growth

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Economics, Rochester Institute of Technology, Rochester, NY, USA
2Department of Spatial Economics, Free University, Amsterdam, Netherlands

author-notes.corresp: Amitrajeet A. Batabyal, Department of Economics, Rochester Institute of Technology, 92 Lomb Memorial Drive, Rochester, NY 14623, USA. Email: aabgsh@rit.edu

abstract.p: The authors provide the first theoretical analysis of a one-sector, discrete-time, Schumpeterian model of growth in a regional economy in which consumers are risk neutral, there is no population growth, monopolistic entrepreneurs produce intermediate goods, and a single consumption good is produced competitively. The authors' analysis generates several new results. In the deterministic model, R&D in time t surely leads to an innovation in time t + 1. In this setting, the authors show that relative to the balanced growth path (BGP) equilibrium, the social planner always allocates more labor to R&D and hence achieves a larger size of innovation and a higher growth rate. Next, in the stochastic model, R&D in time t probabilistically leads to an innovation in time t + 1. In this setting, the authors first define the equilibrium and the steady state BGP allocations. Second, the authors generalize the notion of the steady state and determine the number of unemployed workers. Third, the authors show that the regional economy experiences bursts of unemployment followed by periods of full employment. Finally, the authors show that a decline in the time discount rate increases the average growth rate and the average unemployment.

sec.title: Review of the Literature
sec.p: Contemporary research on entrepreneurship in the context of regional economic growth and development has emphasized three noteworthy points.1 First, entrepreneurship involves an intertemporal process in which new firms are being created, existing firms are growing, and unsuccessful firms are winding down their operations. As noted by Fischer and Nijkamp (2009, 184), this “can be thought of in terms of the Schumpeterian notion of creative destruction.” Second, entrepreneurship involves control of this intertemporal process by the entrepreneur/owner who also serves as a manager of risk. Finally, entrepreneurship entails innovation in a probabilistic and competitive market environment.

In addition to emphasizing the above three points, the sizable but mainly empirical and case study-based literature on the trinity of entrepreneurship, innovation, and regional economic growth has addressed a number of other pertinent issues. For instance, Lorentzen (2008) has used network theory and empirical results to argue that firms find knowledge sources on different spatial scales and that global networks and knowledge sources are very beneficial to them. Michael and Pearce (2009) note that through innovation, entrepreneurship creates wealth for both individuals and nations. Therefore, these authors contend that it makes sense for governments to support entrepreneurship because by doing so, these same governments are actually encouraging innovation. Nijkamp (2009) pays particular attention to what he calls the regional action space of entrepreneurs and then he surveys the nexuses between entrepreneurship and regional economic growth. In their study of the role of regional clusters on regional entrepreneurship, Delgado, Porter, and Stern (2010) come to two salient conclusions. First, they point out that industries that are located in regions with strong clusters experience higher growth in both start-up employment and in new business formation. Second, they note that strong clusters contribute to the survival of start-up firms. Focusing on what they call divided societies, Friedman and Desivilya (2010) argue that social entrepreneurship can be a very useful strategy for promoting regional development if it is combined with conflict management. Samila and Sorenson (2011) argue plausibly that there is a strong nexus between the availability of venture capital and entrepreneurship. Their specific conclusion is that “venture capital stimulates the creation of more firms than it funds…” (Samila and Sorenson 2011, 338).

Lambson and Phillips (2007) study a discrete-time Schumpeterian growth model and show that in general equilibrium, Bertrand competition results in random switching between monopoly and competitive production. Schwartz and Gothner (2009) empirically analyze the extent to which business incubators have been successful in promoting entrepreneurship, innovation, and regional economic development. Valliere and Peterson (2009) use data from the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor and the Global Competitiveness Report and show that in developed nations, a significant fraction of the economic growth rates can be attributed to high expectation entrepreneurs who exploit national investments in knowledge creation and regulatory freedom. Focusing on the links between knowledge and innovation, Vaz and Nijkamp (2009) develop a “knowledge circuit model” that takes into account all the pertinent stakeholders and then offers a framework for research in applied policy problems. Henderson and Weiler (2010) first sketch the salient relationships between entrepreneurship, innovation, and economic growth and then they empirically assess the relationship between entrepreneurship and job growth across US labor market areas and counties.

To conclude this review of the literature, let us now briefly focus on geographically disparate studies of entrepreneurship and regional economic development. After pointing out that innovations and the capacity to innovate are crucial factors for regional development, Cornett (2009) focuses on Denmark and studies the factors that facilitate regional growth and the mechanisms that stimulate innovative behavior in large-, small-, and medium-sized enterprises. Akgun, Baycan-Levent, and Nijkamp (2010) study the connection between entrepreneurship and “counterurbanization” in Turkey and point out that the pursuit of employment is the key to understanding this salient connection. Audretsch, Dohse, and Niebuhr (2010) study various regions in Germany and note that regions with a high level of knowledge provide more opportunities for entrepreneurship than other regions. In addition, “the diversity of people is more conducive to entrepreneurship than the diversity of firms” (Audretsch, Dohse, and Niebuhr 2010, 55). Focusing on China, Qian (2010) points out that the existing stock of human capital rather than the so-called creative class has a positive influence on the trinity of innovation, entrepreneurship, and regional economic performance. Folmer, Dutta, and Oud (2010) concentrate on the state of West Bengal in India and contend that if the objective of policy is to encourage rural industrial entrepreneurship, then it is important to comprehend that properly functioning capital markets in rural areas can not only stimulate rural industrialization but also such markets can prevent the development of inefficient rural industrial activities. Andersson and Koster (2011) focus on start-up formation in Sweden and point out that the determinants of start-ups are both “sticky” and “durable” and that there is a path dependence in start-up activities in the form of a response mechanism between earlier and current start-ups.

sec.title: Contributions of this Article
sec.p: The articles discussed in the preceding three paragraphs have certainly enhanced our understanding of the many nexuses between the trinity of entrepreneurship, innovation, and regional economic growth. This notwithstanding, there are several areas of research concerning the above mentioned trinity in regional science that are salient but remain either unstudied or inadequately studied. Given this state of affairs, we now make three points to motivate and stress the importance of the questions that comprise the subject matter of this article.

First, entrepreneurship plays an important role in promoting regional economic growth and development. In this regard, Fischer and Nijkamp (2009, 184) correctly note that, “[e]ntrepreneurship…is central to regional economic development.” Fischer and Nijkamp (2009, 183) go on to say that an “entrepreneurial culture is a prerequisite for the wealth of regions…” Finally, Capello and Nijkamp (2009, 2) tell us that “the role of knowledge and entrepreneurship…” is one of the salient research topics in the study of regional economic growth and development.

Second, there are links between entrepreneurship, innovation, Schumpeter’s notion of creative destruction, and regional economic growth and development. The link between entrepreneurship and innovation is obvious. In the words of Fischer and Nijkamp (2009, 185), “entrepreneurship entails innovation.” Similarly and consistent with the discussion in the first paragraph of the “Review of the Literature” section, there is an important link between the idea of creative destruction and regional economic growth and development. Florida (1996, 314, emphasis in original) recognizes this link when he says that “there is a geographic or regional element to the transformative forces which Schumpeter identified as gales of creative destruction…” Pe’er and Vertinsky (2008, 280) also point to this link when they say that “a local process of creative destruction provides an impetus to regional industrial renewal.”

Third, entrepreneurship is dynamic, endogenous, and stochastic, and it along with innovation has a great bearing on regional economic growth. In addition, to the best of our knowledge, there are virtually no theoretical studies that are both dynamic and stochastic in nature and that study the ways in which entrepreneurship and innovation endogenously influence economic growth in a regional economy. Given this state of affairs, in our article, we analyze deterministic and stochastic versions of a stylized one-sector Schumpeterian model of growth in a regional economy in discrete-time in which consumers display constant relative risk aversion (CRRA), there is no population growth, monopolistic entrepreneurs produce intermediate goods of distinct qualities, and a single consumption good is produced competitively. Our use of an endogenous growth model is worthwhile because of three reasons. First, the use of such a model provides clear and analytically tractable answers to complicated questions. Second, our approach allows us to shed light on the “micro-foundations” of the relevant knowledge spillovers and this is a topic that “deserves further attention by future research” (Minerva and Ottaviano 2009, 96). Finally, as noted by Audretsch and Aldridge (2009) and Denti (2009), our perspective is consistent with the approach adopted by the authors of related studies in the extant literature in economics and regional science.

Second, we generalize the notion of the steady state and determine the number of unemployed workers. Third, we show that our regional economy experiences bursts of unemployment followed by periods of full employment. Finally, we point out that a decline in the time discount rate increases the average growth rate and the average unemployment in our regional economy.

The rest of the article is organized as follows. The section titled “Preliminaries” first describes the deterministic version of the one-sector Schumpeterian model that is adapted from the prior work of Grossman and Helpman (1991a, 1991b) and Aghion and Howitt (1992). The section titled “The Equilibrium and the BGP” describes the BGP and then specifies restrictions on the parameters so that the pertinent transversality condition is satisfied. The next section compares the BGP growth rate with the Pareto optimal growth rate and shows that the quality or size of innovations in the BGP equilibrium is too small relative to the size of innovations in the Pareto optimal allocation. The following section titled “Preliminaries” for “The Stochastic Schumpeterian Model” delineates the stochastic version described in the section titled “Preliminaries” for “The Deterministic Schumpeterian Model.” The sections titled “The Steady State and Unemployed Workers,” “Unemployment and Employment Patterns,” and “Average Growth Rate and Unemployment” provide a detailed discussion of the four analytical tasks described in the previous paragraph. The final section concludes and then discusses potential extensions of the research delineated in this article.

sec.title: Preliminaries
sec.p: We begin by focusing on a stylized regional economy that is subject to the forces of innovation. To this end, consider an infinite horizon regional economy in which only a single sector, that is the subject of study in this article, experiences quality improvements over time. Time is discrete. Since we are interested in working with a model of endogenous technology, firms and individuals in our regional economy must ultimately have a choice between different kinds of technologies and, in this regard, greater effort, investment, or research spending ought to lead to the invention of better technologies. These features tell us that there must exist a metaproduction function or a “production function over production functions,” which tells us how new technologies are generated as function of various inputs. Following Acemoglu (2009, 413), we shall refer to this metaproduction function as the “innovation possibilities frontier.” It is important to note that we are using the term inputs in a very general sense. In other words, these inputs can be intermediate goods, machines, or even capital. With this caveat in mind, in the remainder of this article, we shall refer to these inputs as “intermediate goods.”

This means that every unit of quality that is innovated is more valuable to the social planner than to an equilibrium firm which, in turn, implies that the social planner innovates more and achieves a higher growth rate.

The above findings have three practical implications. First, a noninterventionist approach by an appropriate regional authority will not result in the optimal level of either research or growth in the regional economy under study. Put differently, there is an activist role to play for the pertinent regional authority. What kind of activist policy? This leads us to the second implication. Specifically, research subsidies may be needed to increase the growth rate of our regional economy. Third, note that inefficiencies exist in our decentralized regional economy because of the presence of monopoly markups. Therefore, subsidies that are designed to increase the production of intermediate goods are also likely to have a positive impact on the growth rate of our regional economy. This concludes our comparative discussion of the BGP and the Pareto optimal growth rates in our regional economy. We now move on and conduct a detailed analysis of the stochastic version of the basic, deterministic model of this section.

sec.title: Unemployment and Employment Patterns
sec.p: We begin by noting that we have already characterized the dynamic behavior of unemployment in our regional economy in equation (30). In the discussion leading up to equation (30) in the Preliminaries section, we noted that unemployment is positive whenever the labor force has to be retrained to adapt itself to the new technology and it is zero otherwise. However, in the one final good sector Schumpeterian model that we are studying in this section, innovations occur stochastically. Therefore, it is in this sense that our regional economy will feature bursts of unemployment followed by periods of full employment.

In particular, whenever a new innovation occurs—and this happens with probability
Λ (
L R ∗
)
—the regional economy under study experiences unemployment in the following period. In contrast, when no innovation takes place, all workers find jobs in the consumption good sector and the economy experiences full employment. We have seen that creative destruction can lead to the dislocation of previously employed workers who experience a period of unemployment before being employed again. Therefore, from a practical perspective, under some circumstances it may make sense to offer unemployment compensation/job retraining benefits to the dislocated workers. In addition, because creative destruction implies that productive units will have shorter horizons in a regional economy with rapid economic growth, workers in such an economy may be reluctant to make what Acemoglu (2009, 472) calls “a range of relationship-specific investments.” Our last task now is to demonstrate that a decline in the time discount rate
ρ
increases both the average growth rate and the average unemployment in our regional economy.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, we used a Schumpeterian model to conduct, to the best of our knowledge for the first time, an explicitly dynamic and stochastic analysis of the ways in which vertical innovations and entrepreneurial activities interact to endogenously generate growth in a regional economy with a single final (consumption) good sector. We first characterized the equilibrium and the BGP for the deterministic version of our model and then we conducted a comparative analysis of the BGP growth rate with the Pareto optimal growth rate for our regional economy. This analysis showed that relative to the BGP allocation, the social planner always employed more labor in R&D, achieved a larger size or quality of innovation, and hence a higher rate of growth.

Next, we studied the stochastic version of our model and this study led to four outcomes. First, we defined the equilibrium and the steady state BGP allocations for our regional economy. Second, we generalized the notion of the steady state and we ascertained the number of unemployed workers. Third, we showed that our economy experienced bursts of unemployment followed by periods of full employment. Finally, we pointed out that a decline in the interest rate increased the average growth rate and the average unemployment rate in our regional economy.

At several points in the article, we provided practical implications of our analysis. In this regard, two additional points deserve some emphasis. First, it is important to comprehend that when we talk about policy interventions that will possibly close the gap between the BGP (decentralized) equilibrium and the Pareto optimal allocation, we also have to consider the objectives of policy makers in our regional economy. This is a topic that raises questions of political economy, a subject that we have not considered in this article. Second, when considering the role of competition policy in a regional economy of the sort studied in this article, it is pertinent to keep in mind that there will sometimes be a trade-off as far as regional economic growth and welfare are concerned. Specifically, policies that have a salutary impact on welfare may not have a similar effect on economic growth and vice versa, and this too is an issue that we have not addressed in the present article.

The analysis in this article can be extended in a number of directions. Here are two suggestions for extending the research delineated in this article. First, it would be instructive to formalize some of the ideas in Jones, Kierzkowski, and Lurong (2005) and analyze a scenario of the sort studied in this article but with the key difference that the R&D sector is characterized by the presence of agglomeration effects. Second, it would be useful to determine the extent to which an existing modeling framework such as the one employed by Suga (2007) can be used to analyze the innovation/entrepreneurship/growth nexus in a model in which there are multiple open regions that trade with each other. Studies of the connections between innovations, entrepreneurial activities, and economic growth that incorporate these features of the problem into the analysis will increase our understanding of the many and varied forces that collectively lead to the development of dynamic and stochastic regional economies.
